worldpa 1.0.0.0

worldpa: An interface to the World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA)

Nicolas Casajus

2019-11-18

Source: vignettes/worldpa.rmd
worldpa.rmd

Introduction

This R package is an interface to the World Database on Protected Areas (WDPA) hosted in the Protected planet website: https://www.protectedplanet.net. It allows user to download spatial shapefiles of protected areas (PA) at three different levels: country, region or the world.

Installation

To install this package from GitHub, first install the package devtools from the CRAN (if not already installed).

# Install the devtools package   ----------
install.packages("devtools", dependencies = TRUE)

# Install the worldpa package    ----------
devtools::install_github("frbcesab/worldpa", build_vignettes = TRUE)

# Load the worldpa package       ----------
library(worldpa)

Getting started

This package contains four main functions:

  • get_regions(): returns the world regions names according to the UNEP classification
  • get_countries(): returns the world countries names according to the UNEP classification
  • get_isocodes(): returns the ISO3 code of all countries of the world
  • get_wdpa(): downloads world protected areas shapefiles (core function)

Let’s explore the function get_regions().

# Get the world regions names    ----------
get_regions()
## [1] "Africa"                    "Asia & Pacific"           
## [3] "Europe"                    "Latin America & Caribbean"
## [5] "North America"             "Polar"                    
## [7] "West Asia"

This function returns the correct spelling of world regions, useful to set the parameter regions of the function get_wdpa().

Now, let’s take a look at the function get_countries().

# Get the world countries names  ----------
countries <- get_countries()

# Get the number of countries    ----------
length(countries)
## [1] 248
# Print the first ten countries  ----------
countries[1:10]
##  [1] "Afghanistan"         "Åland Islands"       "Albania"            
##  [4] "Algeria"             "American Samoa"      "Andorra"            
##  [7] "Angola"              "Anguilla"            "Antigua and Barbuda"
## [10] "Argentina"

This function returns the correct spelling of world countries, useful to set the parameter countries of the function get_wdpa().

The function get_isocodes() returns the ISO3 code (three-letters acronym) of all countries of the world.

# Get the countries ISO3 codes   ----------
iso3 <- get_isocodes()

# Print the first twenty rows    ----------
head(iso3, 20)
##    region                      country iso3
## 1  Africa                      Algeria  DZA
## 2  Africa                      Burundi  BDI
## 3  Africa                       Angola  AGO
## 4  Africa                     Botswana  BWA
## 5  Africa                        Benin  BEN
## 6  Africa                 Burkina Faso  BFA
## 7  Africa                        Egypt  EGY
## 8  Africa     Central African Republic  CAF
## 9  Africa                     Cameroon  CMR
## 10 Africa Democratic Republic of Congo  COD
## 11 Africa                        Congo  COG
## 12 Africa                        Gabon  GAB
## 13 Africa                Côte D'Ivoire  CIV
## 14 Africa                        Ghana  GHA
## 15 Africa                       Guinea  GIN
## 16 Africa                       Gambia  GMB
## 17 Africa                Guinea-Bissau  GNB
## 18 Africa                        Libya  LBY
## 19 Africa                       Malawi  MWI
## 20 Africa                      Morocco  MAR

Finally, the use of the function get_wdpa() is quite simple:

# Download PA for one country    ----------
get_wdpa(countries = "Spain")

# Download PA for two countries  ----------
get_wdpa(countries = c("Portugal", "Spain"))

# Download PA for one region     ----------
get_wdpa(regions = "Africa")

# Download PA for two regions    ----------
get_wdpa(regions = c("Europe", "Africa"))

# Download PA for the world      ----------
get_wdpa() # Not recommended (too big)

The argument path can be set to change the directory where shapefiles will be written. The default is the current directory. Let’s say we want to save shapefiles in the directory wdpa located on the Desktop:

get_wdpa(countries = "Spain", path = "/Users/username/Desktop/wdpa")   # Unix
get_wdpa(countries = "Spain", path = "C:/Users/username/Desktop/wdpa") # Windows

Note: the function get_wdpa() does not return any object on R: shapefiles are directly written on the hard drive.

Study case

get_wdpa(regions = "Africa", path = "Desktop/WDPA")
